messages.message: It is still resulting in the same error at my end. @Prakhar Are you able to build it?

Nope, I tried a few things.
1. Rebasing to latest 24.01
2. Multiple poetry versions (1.4.1/1.8.2)
3. Deleting poetry virtual env and reinstalling
I am seeing this issue with scikit-learn installation on webdriver-tasks as well. Its possible that the issue is not related to a particular package. Python different python versions for now
build-docker is working fine on my crafting machine with a clean 24.01 branch.  Is this only happening when trying to upgrade something else?

Yeah. Its just on that particular jenkins image. Probably has to do with pip/setuptools version:
`docker run -it --user root -v $IB_HOME:/instabase gcr.io/instabase-build/jenkins:23.09.23.12.18.49 (http://gcr.io/instabase-build/jenkins:23.09.23.12.18.49) /bin/bash`

Looks like for some packages, the backend for installation is not specified so they default to `setuptools.build_meta:__legacy__`. Looking for some way to force all packages to use same backend right now...
I still don't understand, how can I reproduce this? I have to try upgrading a package?
Yes, if you run `poetry add tornado==6.4.1` under `webdriver-tasks` then this error will come
Its coming during package upgrade thingy for vuln fixes

For me, I am seeing this error in 23.07 on running  `make build test` for webdriver tasks inside a jenkins image.

*Edit: I'll create a separate thread to avoid confusion*
webdriver is built successfully consistently on the build machine; try make build-docker instead of make build

@Abhishek /@Prakhar can you try regenerating poetry.lock and requirements.txt from inside of a docker container running the build image? That fixed this issue for me on the 23.07 branch

Edit: I reproduced my changes to pyproject.toml on a fresh branch
